qas.question: What is the name of the world's greatest deposit of bitumen?
Where are the Athabasca oil sands located?
How old are the Athabasca deposits?
What percentage of recovery of bitumen is by oil wells?
Located in the McMurray Formation, what is the smallest deposit of natural bitumen known as?
Located in the Peace River, what is the largest deposit of natural bitumen known as?
The two largest formations occur in the oil sands of which river?
The two largest formations occur in the oil sands of which lake?
What is the other 70% produced by?

context: The world's largest deposit of natural bitumen, known as the <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Athabasca oil sands<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> is located in the McMurray Formation of <a1_0>Northern Alberta<a1_0/>. This formation is from the <a2_0>early Cretaceous<a2_0/>, and is composed of numerous lenses of oil-bearing sand with up to 20% oil. Isotopic studies attribute the oil deposits to be about <a3_0>110 million years<a3_0/> old. Two smaller but still very large formations occur in the <b7_0>Peace River<b7_0/> oil sands and the <b8_0>Cold Lake<b8_0/> oil sands, to the west and southeast of the Athabasca oil sands, respectively. Of the Alberta bitumen deposits, only parts of the Athabasca oil sands are shallow enough to be suitable for surface mining. The other <a4_0>80%<a4_0/> has to be produced by <b9_0>oil wells<b9_0/> using enhanced oil recovery techniques like steam-assisted gravity drainage.
